mn25:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn25:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn25:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn25:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, a sower does not sow seed for deer thinking,
mn25:2.1.comm: “Sower sows seed” renders the triplicated expression nevāpiko nivāpaṁ nivapati. The root sense of vap is to “cast down” or “sow” seed; it is also used of offerings for the ancestors in the śrāddha ceremony. It is tempting to translate this phrase as a “trapper” who lays “bait”. But the aim of the “sower” is simply to grow a crop, and to do this they need to keep the deer out. That is the guile of the story: they appear harmless. | For an amicable solution to this problem, see the conclusion to the Rurumigarāja Jātaka (Ja 482) | Migajāta (“deer”) might be better translated as “wild animals” here.

mn25:2.2.pli: ‘imaṃ me nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ migajātā paribhuñjantā dīghāyukā vaṇṇavanto ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ yāpentū’ti.
mn25:2.2.eng: ‘May the deer, enjoying this seed, be long-lived and beautiful. May they live long and prosper!’

mn25:2.3.pli: Evañca kho, bhikkhave, nevāpiko nivāpaṃ nivapati migajātānaṃ:
mn25:2.3.eng: A sower sows seed for deer thinking,

mn25:2.4.pli: ‘imaṃ me nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ migajātā anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjissanti, anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā madaṃ āpajjissanti, mattā samānā pamādaṃ āpajjissanti, pamattā samānā yathākāmakaraṇīyā bhavissanti imasmiṃ nivāpe’ti.
mn25:2.4.eng: ‘When these deer encroach on where I sow the seed, they’ll recklessly enjoy eating it. They’ll become indulgent, then they’ll become negligent, and then I’ll be able to do what I want with them on account of this seed.’

mn25:3.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, paṭhamā migajātā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu, te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, mattā samānā pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, pamattā samānā yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ nevāpikassa amusmiṃ nivāpe.
mn25:3.1.eng: And indeed, the first herd of deer encroached on where the sower sowed the seed and recklessly enjoyed eating it. They became indulgent, then they became negligent, and then the sower was able to do what he wanted with them on account of that seed.

mn25:3.2.pli: Evañhi te, bhikkhave, paṭhamā migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:3.2.eng: And that’s how the first herd of deer failed to get free from the sower’s power.

mn25:4.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, dutiyā migajātā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
mn25:4.1.eng: So then a second herd of deer thought up a plan,

mn25:4.2.pli: ‘ye kho te paṭhamā migajātā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu.
mn25:4.2.eng: ‘The first herd of deer became indulgent …

mn25:4.3.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, mattā samānā pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, pamattā samānā yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ nevāpikassa amusmiṃ nivāpe.

mn25:4.4.pli: Evañhi te paṭhamā migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:4.4.eng: and failed to get free of the sower’s power.

mn25:4.5.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ sabbaso nivāpabhojanā paṭivirameyyāma, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihareyyāmā’ti.
mn25:4.5.eng: Why don’t we refrain from eating the seed altogether? Avoiding dangerous food, we can venture deep into a wilderness region and live there.’

mn25:4.6.pli: Te sabbaso nivāpabhojanā paṭiviramiṃsu, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihariṃsu.
mn25:4.6.eng: And that’s just what they did.

mn25:4.7.pli: Tesaṃ gimhānaṃ pacchime māse, tiṇodakasaṅkhaye, adhimattakasimānaṃ patto kāyo hoti.
mn25:4.7.eng: But when it came to the last month of summer, the grass and water ran out. Their bodies became much too thin,

mn25:4.8.eng: and they lost their strength and energy.

mn25:4.9.pli: Balavīriye parihīne tameva nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa paccāgamiṃsu.
mn25:4.9.eng: So they returned to where the sower had sown the seed.

mn25:4.10.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu.
mn25:4.10.eng: Encroaching, they recklessly enjoyed eating it …

mn25:4.11.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, mattā samānā pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, pamattā samānā yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ nevāpikassa amusmiṃ nivāpe.

mn25:4.12.pli: Evañhi te, bhikkhave, dutiyāpi migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:4.12.eng: And that’s how the second herd of deer failed to get free from the sower’s power.

mn25:5.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, tatiyā migajātā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
mn25:5.1.eng: So then a third herd of deer thought up a plan,

mn25:5.2.pli: ‘ye kho te paṭhamā migajātā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa …pe…

mn25:5.3.pli: evañhi te paṭhamā migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:5.4.pli: Yepi te dutiyā migajātā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:

mn25:5.5.pli: “ye kho te paṭhamā migajātā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa …pe…

mn25:5.6.pli: evañhi te paṭhamā migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:5.7.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ sabbaso nivāpabhojanā paṭivirameyyāma, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihareyyāmā”ti.

mn25:5.8.pli: Te sabbaso nivāpabhojanā paṭiviramiṃsu, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihariṃsu.

mn25:5.9.pli: Tesaṃ gimhānaṃ pacchime māse tiṇodakasaṅkhaye adhimattakasimānaṃ patto kāyo hoti.

mn25:5.11.pli: Balavīriye parihīne tameva nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa paccāgamiṃsu.

mn25:5.12.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu.

mn25:5.13.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, mattā samānā pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, pamattā samānā yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ nevāpikassa amusmiṃ nivāpe.

mn25:5.14.pli: Evañhi te dutiyāpi migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:5.14.eng: failed to get free of the sower’s power.

mn25:5.15.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa upanissāya āsayaṃ kappeyyāma.
mn25:5.15.eng: Why don’t we set up our lair close by where the sower has sown the seed?

mn25:5.16.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjissāma, ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjissāma, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjissāma, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā bhavissāma nevāpikassa amusmiṃ nivāpe’ti.
mn25:5.16.eng: Then we can encroach and enjoy eating without being reckless. We won’t become indulgent, then we won’t become negligent, and then the sower won’t be able to do what he wants with us on account of that seed.’

mn25:5.17.pli: Te amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa upanissāya āsayaṃ kappayiṃsu.
mn25:5.17.eng: And that’s just what they did.

mn25:5.18.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu, te tattha ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ nevāpikassa amusmiṃ nivāpe.

mn25:5.19.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, nevāpikassa ca nevāpikaparisāya ca etadahosi:
mn25:5.19.eng: So the sower and his helpers thought,

mn25:5.20.pli: ‘saṭhāssunāmime tatiyā migajātā ketabino, iddhimantāssunāmime tatiyā migajātā parajanā;
mn25:5.20.eng: ‘Wow, this third herd of deer is so sneaky and devious, they must be some kind of strange spirits with magical abilities!
mn25:5.20.comm: The repeated nāma is strongly emphatic. | Parajana sometimes means “stranger” (Mil 6.3.1:13.2), but the commentary here glosses it as yakkha, and a yakkha named Parajana makes an appearance in (MN 31:21.1). Presumably it has a sense not dissimilar to amanussa, “non-human”. Compare the itarajanā of Atharvaveda Saṁhita 8.10.28a.

mn25:5.21.pli: imañca nāma nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ paribhuñjanti, na ca nesaṃ jānāma āgatiṃ vā gatiṃ vā.
mn25:5.21.eng: For they eat the seed we’ve sown without us knowing how they come and go.

mn25:5.22.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ imaṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mahatīhi daṇḍavākarāhi samantā sappadesaṃ anuparivāreyyāma, appeva nāma tatiyānaṃ migajātānaṃ āsayaṃ passeyyāma, yattha te gāhaṃ gaccheyyun’ti.
mn25:5.22.eng: Why don’t we surround the seed on all sides by staking out high nets? Hopefully we might get to see the lair where they go to hide out.’
mn25:5.22.comm: Vākarā (variant vāgurā, which is also the Sanskrit form) is a net or snare, which here is staked out on sticks. The deer would have to leap over it, revealing their position. | Gāha here is from √gāh (“deep place, hidey-hole”) rather than √gah (“take”).

mn25:5.23.pli: Te amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mahatīhi daṇḍavākarāhi samantā sappadesaṃ anuparivāresuṃ.
mn25:5.23.eng: And that’s just what they did.

mn25:5.24.pli: Addasaṃsu kho, bhikkhave, nevāpiko ca nevāpikaparisā ca tatiyānaṃ migajātānaṃ āsayaṃ, yattha te gāhaṃ agamaṃsu.
mn25:5.24.eng: And they saw the lair where the third herd of deer went to hide out.

mn25:5.25.pli: Evañhi te, bhikkhave, tatiyāpi migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:5.25.eng: And that’s how the third herd failed to get free from the sower’s power.

mn25:6.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, catutthā migajātā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
mn25:6.1.eng: So then a fourth herd of deer thought up a plan,

mn25:6.3.pli: evañhi te paṭhamā migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:6.4.pli: Yepi te dutiyā migajātā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:

mn25:6.6.pli: evañhi te paṭhamā migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:6.7.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ sabbaso nivāpabhojanā paṭivirameyyāma, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihareyyāmā”ti.

mn25:6.9.pli: evañhi te dutiyāpi migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:6.10.pli: Yepi te tatiyā migajātā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:

mn25:6.12.pli: evañhi te paṭhamā migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:6.13.pli: Yepi te dutiyā migajātā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:

mn25:6.15.pli: evañhi te paṭhamā migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:6.16.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ sabbaso nivāpabhojanā paṭivirameyyāma, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihareyyāmā’ti.

mn25:6.18.pli: evañhi te dutiyāpi migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:6.19.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa upanissāya āsayaṃ kappeyyāma, tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjissāma, ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjissāma, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjissāma, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā bhavissāma nevāpikassa amusmiṃ nivāpe”ti.

mn25:6.20.pli: Te amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa upanissāya āsayaṃ kappayiṃsu, tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu, te tattha ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ nevāpikassa amusmiṃ nivāpe.

mn25:6.21.pli: Tatra nevāpikassa ca nevāpikaparisāya ca etadahosi:

mn25:6.22.pli: “saṭhāssunāmime tatiyā migajātā ketabino, iddhimantāssunāmime tatiyā migajātā parajanā, imañca nāma nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ paribhuñjanti.

mn25:6.23.pli: Na ca nesaṃ jānāma āgatiṃ vā gatiṃ vā.

mn25:6.24.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ imaṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mahatīhi daṇḍavākarāhi samantā sappadesaṃ anuparivāreyyāma, appeva nāma tatiyānaṃ migajātānaṃ āsayaṃ passeyyāma, yattha te gāhaṃ gaccheyyun”ti.

mn25:6.25.pli: Te amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mahatīhi daṇḍavākarāhi samantā sappadesaṃ anuparivāresuṃ.

mn25:6.26.pli: Addasaṃsu kho nevāpiko ca nevāpikaparisā ca tatiyānaṃ migajātānaṃ āsayaṃ, yattha te gāhaṃ agamaṃsu.

mn25:6.27.pli: Evañhi te tatiyāpi migajātā na parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:6.27.eng: failed to get free of the sower’s power.

mn25:6.28.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yattha agati nevāpikassa ca nevāpikaparisāya ca tatrāsayaṃ kappeyyāma, tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjissāma, ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjissāma, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjissāma, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā bhavissāma nevāpikassa amusmiṃ nivāpe’ti.
mn25:6.28.eng: Why don’t we set up our lair somewhere the sower and his helpers can’t go? Then we can intrude on where the sower has sown the seed and enjoy eating it without being reckless. We won’t become indulgent, then we won’t become negligent, and then the sower won’t be able to do with us what he wants on account of that seed.’

mn25:6.29.pli: Te yattha agati nevāpikassa ca nevāpikaparisāya ca tatrāsayaṃ kappayiṃsu.
mn25:6.29.eng: And that’s just what they did.

mn25:6.30.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ nevāpikassa ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu, te tattha ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ nevāpikassa amusmiṃ nivāpe.

mn25:6.31.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, nevāpikassa ca nevāpikaparisāya ca etadahosi:
mn25:6.31.eng: So the sower and his helpers thought,

mn25:6.32.pli: ‘saṭhāssunāmime catutthā migajātā ketabino, iddhimantāssunāmime catutthā migajātā parajanā.
mn25:6.32.eng: ‘Wow, this fourth herd of deer is so sneaky and devious, they must be some kind of strange spirits with magical abilities!

mn25:6.33.pli: Imañca nāma nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ paribhuñjanti, na ca nesaṃ jānāma āgatiṃ vā gatiṃ vā.
mn25:6.33.eng: For they eat the seed we’ve sown without us knowing how they come and go.

mn25:6.34.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ imaṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mahatīhi daṇḍavākarāhi samantā sappadesaṃ anuparivāreyyāma, appeva nāma catutthānaṃ migajātānaṃ āsayaṃ passeyyāma yattha te gāhaṃ gaccheyyun’ti.
mn25:6.34.eng: Why don’t we surround the seed on all sides by staking out high nets? Hopefully we might get to see the lair where they go to hide out.’

mn25:6.35.pli: Te amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mahatīhi daṇḍavākarāhi samantā sappadesaṃ anuparivāresuṃ.
mn25:6.35.eng: And that’s just what they did.

mn25:6.36.pli: Neva kho, bhikkhave, addasaṃsu nevāpiko ca nevāpikaparisā ca catutthānaṃ migajātānaṃ āsayaṃ, yattha te gāhaṃ gaccheyyuṃ.
mn25:6.36.eng: But they couldn’t see the lair where the fourth herd of deer went to hide out.

mn25:6.37.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, nevāpikassa ca nevāpikaparisāya ca etadahosi:
mn25:6.37.eng: So the sower and his helpers thought,

mn25:6.38.pli: ‘sace kho mayaṃ catutthe migajāte ghaṭṭessāma, te ghaṭṭitā aññe ghaṭṭissanti te ghaṭṭitā aññe ghaṭṭissanti.
mn25:6.38.eng: ‘If we disturb this fourth herd of deer, they’ll disturb others, who in turn will disturb even more.

mn25:6.39.pli: Evaṃ imaṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ sabbaso migajātā parimuñcissanti.
mn25:6.39.eng: Then all of the deer will escape this seed we’ve sown.

mn25:6.40.eng: Why don’t we just keep an eye on that fourth herd?’

mn25:6.41.pli: Ajjhupekkhiṃsu kho, bhikkhave, nevāpiko ca nevāpikaparisā ca catutthe migajāte.
mn25:6.41.eng: And that’s just what they did.

mn25:6.42.pli: Evañhi te, bhikkhave, catutthā migajātā parimucciṃsu nevāpikassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:6.42.eng: And that’s how the fourth herd of deer escaped the sower’s power.

mn25:7.1.pli: Upamā kho me ayaṃ, bhikkhave, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
mn25:7.1.eng: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.

mn25:7.2.eng: And this is what it means.

mn25:7.3.pli: nivāpoti kho, bhikkhave, pañcannetaṃ kāmaguṇānaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
mn25:7.3.eng: ‘Seed’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn25:7.4.pli: Nevāpikoti kho, bhikkhave, mārassetaṃ pāpimato adhivacanaṃ.
mn25:7.4.eng: ‘Sower’ is a term for Māra the Wicked.

mn25:7.5.eng: ‘Sower’s helpers’ is a term for Māra’s assembly.

mn25:7.6.eng: ‘Deer’ is a term for ascetics and brahmins.

mn25:8.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu.
mn25:8.1.eng: Now, the first group of ascetics and brahmins encroached on where the seed and the worldly pleasures of the flesh were sown by Māra and recklessly enjoyed eating it.

mn25:8.2.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, mattā samānā pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, pamattā samānā yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ mārassa amusmiṃ nivāpe amusmiñca lokāmise.
mn25:8.2.eng: They became indulgent, then they became negligent, and then Māra was able to do what he wanted with them on account of that seed and the worldly pleasures of the flesh.

mn25:8.3.pli: Evañhi te, bhikkhave, paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:8.3.eng: And that’s how the first group of ascetics and brahmins failed to get free from Māra’s power.

mn25:8.4.pli: Seyyathāpi te, bhikkhave, paṭhamā migajātā tathūpame ahaṃ ime paṭhame samaṇabrāhmaṇe vadāmi.
mn25:8.4.eng: This first group of ascetics and brahmins is just like the first herd of deer, I say.

mn25:9.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, dutiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
mn25:9.1.eng: So then a second group of ascetics and brahmins thought up a plan,

mn25:9.2.pli: ‘ye kho te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu.
mn25:9.2.eng: ‘The first group of ascetics and brahmins became indulgent …

mn25:9.3.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, mattā samānā pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, pamattā samānā yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ mārassa amusmiṃ nivāpe amusmiñca lokāmise.

mn25:9.4.pli: Evañhi te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:9.4.eng: and failed to get free of Māra’s power.

mn25:9.5.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ sabbaso nivāpabhojanā lokāmisā paṭivirameyyāma, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihareyyāmā’ti.
mn25:9.5.eng: Why don’t we refrain from eating the seed and the worldly pleasures of the flesh altogether? Avoiding dangerous food, we can venture deep into a wilderness region and live there.’
mn25:9.5.comm: Following this the Mahāsaṅgīti edition has a ghost sentence, formed by adding the first part of the subsequent sentence with the second part of the previous. It is absent from the PTS text.

mn25:9.6.pli: Te sabbaso nivāpabhojanā lokāmisā paṭiviramiṃsu, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihareyyāmāti.

mn25:9.7.pli: Te sabbaso nivāpabhojanā lokāmisā paṭiviramiṃsu, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihariṃsu.
mn25:9.7.eng: And that’s just what they did.

mn25:9.8.pli: Te tattha sākabhakkhāpi ahesuṃ, sāmākabhakkhāpi ahesuṃ, nīvārabhakkhāpi ahesuṃ, daddulabhakkhāpi ahesuṃ, haṭabhakkhāpi ahesuṃ, kaṇabhakkhāpi ahesuṃ, ācāmabhakkhāpi ahesuṃ, piññākabhakkhāpi ahesuṃ, tiṇabhakkhāpi ahesuṃ, gomayabhakkhāpi ahesuṃ, vanamūlaphalāhārā yāpesuṃ pavattaphalabhojī.
mn25:9.8.eng: They ate herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survived on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.

mn25:9.9.pli: Tesaṃ gimhānaṃ pacchime māse, tiṇodakasaṅkhaye, adhimattakasimānaṃ patto kāyo hoti.
mn25:9.9.eng: But when it came to the last month of summer, the grass and water ran out. Their bodies became much too thin,

mn25:9.10.eng: and they lost their strength and energy.

mn25:9.11.eng: Because of this, they lost their heart’s release,
mn25:9.11.comm: “Heart’s release” (cetovimutti) is a term for the meditative absorptions, which are listed below. | While these meditators did indeed escape Māra for a while, from the point of view of the eightfold path, they were neglecting right livelihood. A Buddhist mendicant relies on alms, which not only ensures adequate nutrition, but helps build community and spread the Dhamma. | For the dependency of absorption on food, see also the Buddha’s account of his own practice before awakening (MN 36:33.2).

mn25:9.12.pli: Cetovimuttiyā parihīnāya tameva nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa paccāgamiṃsu tāni ca lokāmisāni.
mn25:9.12.eng: so they went back to where Māra had sown the seed and the worldly pleasures of the flesh.

mn25:9.13.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu.
mn25:9.13.eng: Intruding on that place, they recklessly enjoyed eating them …

mn25:9.14.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, mattā samānā pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, pamattā samānā yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ mārassa amusmiṃ nivāpe amusmiñca lokāmise.

mn25:9.15.pli: Evañhi te, bhikkhave, dutiyāpi samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:9.15.eng: And that’s how the second group of ascetics and brahmins failed to get free from Māra’s power.

mn25:9.16.pli: Seyyathāpi te, bhikkhave, dutiyā migajātā tathūpame ahaṃ ime dutiye samaṇabrāhmaṇe vadāmi.
mn25:9.16.eng: This second group of ascetics and brahmins is just like the second herd of deer, I say.

mn25:10.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, tatiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
mn25:10.1.eng: So then a third group of ascetics and brahmins thought up a plan,

mn25:10.2.pli: ‘ye kho te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni …pe….

mn25:10.3.pli: Evañhi te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:10.4.pli: Yepi te dutiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
mn25:10.4.eng: and second groups of ascetics and brahmins …

mn25:10.5.pli: “ye kho te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni …pe….

mn25:10.6.pli: Evañhi te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:10.7.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ sabbaso nivāpabhojanā lokāmisā paṭivirameyyāma, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihareyyāmā”ti.

mn25:10.11.pli: Tesaṃ gimhānaṃ pacchime māse tiṇodakasaṅkhaye adhimattakasimānaṃ patto kāyo hoti.

mn25:10.12.pli: Tesaṃ adhimattakasimānaṃ pattakāyānaṃ balavīriyaṃ parihāyi, balavīriye parihīne cetovimutti parihāyi, cetovimuttiyā parihīnāya tameva nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa paccāgamiṃsu tāni ca lokāmisāni.

mn25:10.13.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu.

mn25:10.14.pli: Te tattha anupakhajja mucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, mattā samānā pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, pamattā samānā yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ mārassa amusmiṃ nivāpe amusmiñca lokāmise.

mn25:10.15.pli: Evañhi te dutiyāpi samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:10.15.eng: failed to get free of Māra’s power.

mn25:10.16.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni upanissāya āsayaṃ kappeyyāma, tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjissāma, ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjissāma, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjissāma, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā bhavissāma mārassa amusmiṃ nivāpe amusmiñca lokāmise’ti.
mn25:10.16.eng: Why don’t we set up our lair close by where Māra has sown the seed and those worldly pleasures of the flesh? Then we can encroach on it and enjoy eating without being reckless. We won’t become indulgent, then we won’t become negligent, and then Māra won’t be able to do what he wants with us on account of that seed and those worldly pleasures of the flesh.’

mn25:10.17.pli: Te amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni upanissāya āsayaṃ kappayiṃsu.
mn25:10.17.eng: And that’s just what they did.

mn25:10.18.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu.

mn25:10.19.pli: Te tattha ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ mārassa amusmiṃ nivāpe amusmiñca lokāmise.

mn25:10.20.eng: Still, they had such views as these:
mn25:10.20.comm: This group failed to develop right view. For more on these speculative views, see MN 63 and MN 72.

mn25:10.21.pli: sassato loko itipi, asassato loko itipi;
mn25:10.21.eng: ‘The cosmos is eternal’ or ‘The cosmos is not eternal’;
mn25:10.21.comm: This is the famous list of ten “undeclared points”, which are found throughout the suttas (eg. DN 9:25.3, MN 63:2.3, MN 72:3.1, and the whole of SN 44). They seem to have functioned as a kind of checklist by which philosophers could be evaluated and classified. In the Jain Bhagavatisūtra 9.33, Indrabhūti Gautama tests the impostor Jamāli’s bona fides by asking about the eternity of the world and the soul. When Jamāli failed to answer, Mahāvīra stepped in, explaining that both the soul and the world are in one sense eternal since they last forever, but in another sense they are transient since they go through different phases. | The word loka occurs in a number of senses, but here it refers to the entire “cosmos” of countless worlds.

mn25:10.22.pli: antavā loko itipi, anantavā loko itipi;
mn25:10.22.eng: ‘The cosmos is finite’ or ‘The cosmos is infinite’;

mn25:10.23.pli: taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ itipi, aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīraṃ itipi;
mn25:10.23.eng: ‘The soul and the body are one and the same’ or ‘The soul is one thing, the body another’;

mn25:10.24.pli: hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā itipi, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā itipi, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā itipi, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā itipi.
mn25:10.24.eng: or that after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.

mn25:10.25.pli: Evañhi te, bhikkhave, tatiyāpi samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:10.25.eng: And that’s how the third group of ascetics and brahmins failed to get free from Māra’s power.

mn25:10.26.pli: Seyyathāpi te, bhikkhave, tatiyā migajātā tathūpame ahaṃ ime tatiye samaṇabrāhmaṇe vadāmi.
mn25:10.26.eng: This third group of ascetics and brahmins is just like the third herd of deer, I say.

mn25:11.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, catutthā samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
mn25:11.1.eng: So then a fourth group of ascetics and brahmins thought up a plan,

mn25:11.2.pli: ‘ye kho te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa …pe….

mn25:11.3.pli: Evañhi te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:11.4.pli: Yepi te dutiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃ samacintesuṃ:

mn25:11.6.pli: Evañhi te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:11.7.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ sabbaso nivāpabhojanā lokāmisā paṭivirameyyāma bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihareyyāmā’ti.

mn25:11.9.pli: Evañhi te dutiyāpi samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:11.10.pli: Yepi te tatiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃ samacintesuṃ ye kho te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā …pe….
mn25:11.10.eng: and third groups of ascetics and brahmins …

mn25:11.11.pli: Evañhi te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:11.12.pli: Yepi te dutiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃ samacintesuṃ ye kho te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā …pe….

mn25:11.13.pli: Evañhi te paṭhamā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:11.14.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ sabbaso nivāpabhojanā lokāmisā paṭivirameyyāma, bhayabhogā paṭiviratā araññāyatanāni ajjhogāhetvā vihareyyāmā’ti.

mn25:11.16.pli: Evañhi te dutiyāpi samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.

mn25:11.17.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni upanissāya āsayaṃ kappeyyāma.

mn25:11.18.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjissāma, ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjissāma, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjissāma, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā bhavissāma mārassa amusmiṃ nivāpe amusmiñca lokāmiseti.

mn25:11.19.pli: Te amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni upanissāya āsayaṃ kappayiṃsu.

mn25:11.20.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu.

mn25:11.21.pli: Te tattha ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjiṃsu.

mn25:11.23.pli: Appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ mārassa amusmiṃ nivāpe amusmiñca lokāmise.

mn25:11.24.pli: Api ca kho evaṃdiṭṭhikā ahesuṃ sassato loko itipi …pe…

mn25:11.25.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā itipi.

mn25:11.26.pli: Evañhi te tatiyāpi samaṇabrāhmaṇā na parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:11.26.eng: failed to get free of Māra’s power.

mn25:11.27.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ yattha agati mārassa ca māraparisāya ca tatrāsayaṃ kappeyyāma.
mn25:11.27.eng: Why don’t we set up our lair where Māra and his assembly can’t go?

mn25:11.28.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjissāma, ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjissāma, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjissāma, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā bhavissāma mārassa amusmiṃ nivāpe amusmiñca lokāmiseti.
mn25:11.28.eng: Then we can encroach on where Māra has sown the seed and those worldly pleasures of the flesh, and enjoy eating without being reckless. We won’t become indulgent, then we won’t become negligent, and then Māra won’t be able to do what he wants with us on account of that seed and those worldly pleasures of the flesh.’

mn25:11.29.pli: Te yattha agati mārassa ca māraparisāya ca tatrāsayaṃ kappayiṃsu.
mn25:11.29.eng: And that’s just what they did.

mn25:11.30.pli: Tatrāsayaṃ kappetvā amuṃ nivāpaṃ nivuttaṃ mārassa amūni ca lokāmisāni ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjiṃsu, te tattha ananupakhajja amucchitā bhojanāni bhuñjamānā na madaṃ āpajjiṃsu, amattā samānā na pamādaṃ āpajjiṃsu, appamattā samānā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā ahesuṃ mārassa amusmiṃ nivāpe amusmiñca lokāmise.

mn25:11.31.pli: Evañhi te, bhikkhave, catutthā samaṇabrāhmaṇā parimucciṃsu mārassa iddhānubhāvā.
mn25:11.31.eng: And that’s how the fourth group of ascetics and brahmins got free from Māra’s power.

mn25:11.32.pli: Seyyathāpi te, bhikkhave, catutthā migajātā tathūpame ahaṃ ime catutthe samaṇabrāhmaṇe vadāmi.
mn25:11.32.eng: This fourth group of ascetics and brahmins is just like the fourth herd of deer, I say.

mn25:12.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, agati mārassa ca māraparisāya ca?
mn25:12.1.eng: And where is it that Māra and his assembly can’t go?

mn25:12.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn25:12.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn25:12.2.comm: Here the text shifts from “ascetics and brahmins”—that is, any kind of religious practitioner—to “mendicants”, who were Buddhist alms-gatherers. Having learned the importance of right livelihood and right view, they are now practicing absorption as part of the noble eightfold path.

mn25:12.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu andhamakāsi māraṃ, apadaṃ vadhitvā māracakkhuṃ adassanaṃ gato pāpimato.
mn25:12.3.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.

mn25:13.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn25:13.1.eng: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn25:13.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …

mn25:14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn25:14.1.eng: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

mn25:14.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …

mn25:15.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn25:15.1.eng: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

mn25:15.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …

mn25:16.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn25:16.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

mn25:16.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …

mn25:17.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn25:17.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

mn25:17.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …

mn25:18.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn25:18.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

mn25:18.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …

mn25:19.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn25:19.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn25:19.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …

mn25:20.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati. Paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
mn25:20.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.
mn25:20.1.comm: The “cessation of perception and feeling” (saññāvedayitanirodha) is a culminating meditation state of supreme subtlety that often leads directly to awakening (but see AN 5.166). The state itself, like all meditation states, is temporary, but afterwards the defilements can be eliminated forever. This liberating insight is the consequence of the balanced development of all eight factors of the path.

mn25:20.2.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu andhamakāsi māraṃ, apadaṃ vadhitvā māracakkhuṃ adassanaṃ gato pāpimato tiṇṇo loke visattikan”ti.
mn25:20.2.eng: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see. And they’ve crossed over clinging to the world.”

mn25:20.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn25:20.4.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn25:20.4.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
